comments:
Statistics 101 develops ideas for helping to make decisions based on data.  Some of the following material is covered: data displays and summary statistics for quantitative and qualitative variables; correlation and simple regression for pairs of variables; probability as a measure of uncertainty and as limiting relative frequency; the law of large numbers; the normal distribution and the central limit theorem; statistical inference based on standard errors, confidence intervals and statistical hypothesis tests. The course does not dwell on the details of computation—its main focus is on understanding a few deep concepts and interpreting data and statistical results.

Students widely agreed that “the class [spent] too much time focused on how to use the R software rather than on actual statistics.”  The professor presented R code during class, which almost all students found boring and “difficult to follow,” especially since they were not allowed to use their laptops to follow along.  A lot of students felt that the focus on R code “[made] it difficult to grasp the actual concept[s],” and several mentioned that lectures were “ineffective.”  A number of students also mentioned that the overly heavy focus on R extended to the homework assignments; all the comments about the homework noted that the focus on R coding made it time-consuming and difficult.  In the end, many students tried to learn the material independently.  While some found independent learning difficult due to a lack of lecture notes beyond the text files containing R code that were presented in class, the few students who attended office hours said they were “very useful.”  

On average, students found Professor Buja to be “personable” and “approachable” but most believed he “[did] not do a good job of communicating with students” during lecture.  In contrast, the students who commented on office hours felt that Professor Buja was “very helpful” in that setting.    

Almost all students felt that the focus on R made the course difficult.  Students who were less comfortable with R found the homework, which was based on R, to be challenging and warned that it “[could] take a long time to do.”  Students also felt that the exams were disjointed from the class as they did not test R; some found it “difficult to distill [from the lectures] what statistics information…[was] necessary for the tests.”  Statistics 101 is part of the Wharton core.  Math 104 or equivalent is required as a prerequisite.
